steps.title: Decide which part of the wiper you need to replace.
steps.content: Decide which part of the wiper you need to replace. The wiper assembly consists of two parts: the arm and a wiper blade that attaches to the metal arm. The rubber insert that rests against the glass of the windshield is for the most part is not available separately. If the wiper blade isn’t resting against the glass with enough tension or has become bent, you’ll need to replace the entire blade.

steps.title: Buy the proper blades for your car model at an automotive-supply store.
steps.content: Buy the proper blades for your car model at an automotive-supply store. Ask a salesperson to help you select the right wipers, or, alternatively, measure each of the old wipers first and bring the measurements with you into the store. [2] X Research source Remember that the left and right wiper blades may be different lengths.

steps.title: Pull the entire wiper assembly arm away from the windshield and into a standing position.
steps.content: Pull the entire wiper assembly arm away from the windshield and into a standing position. Move the wiper into a position perpendicular to the metal arm. Repeat with the other wiper arm. Some wipers will only come two to three inches away from the windshield; if that’s the case, don’t try to force the wipers up any further. On some cars it may be easier to turn on the wipers and when they start to move turn off the ignition. This will allow you to move the arm up to have better access to remove the wiper blade.

steps.title: Release the wiper blade.
steps.content: Release the wiper blade. Locate the small tab on the underside of wiper blade (near where the rubber insert meets the metal arm), then push it in (or in some cases, pull on it) to release. Pull down on the blade and it should then slide off the hook of the metal arm. [3] X Research source You may need to tap or tug on the blade a bit to remove it if there’s built up debris or corrosion. Sometimes it helps to push the wiper up into the holder, press the tab, and then remove. The bare metal arms are now exposed, and, if left in the standing position, they can snap back and damage your windshield. So, to be safe, gently place the metal arms back against the windshield until you’re ready to put on the new ones. To be extra safe, place a rag or cloth underneath the metal arm while it rests on the windshield.

steps.title: Take out the new wiper.
steps.content: Take out the new wiper. If the left and right wipers are different sizes, be sure to match the new wiper to the correct side. Push the movable hinge on the new blade until the hinge is perpendicular to the rest of the blade.

steps.title: Line the new blade up with the metal arm so that the metal hook will go through the hole in the blade.
steps.content: Line the new blade up with the metal arm so that the metal hook will go through the hole in the blade. Push the metal hook through the hole in the blade. [4] X Research source The metal hook should push up against the rubber insert.

steps.title: Pull up on the blade until you hear as well as feel it click it into place.
steps.content: Pull up on the blade until you hear as well as feel it click it into place. Gently push the blade back down to a resting position against the windshield. [5] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source Repeat with the other wiper blade.

steps.title: Check the wiper arm angle.
steps.content: Check the wiper arm angle. If the wiper arm angle is off it can cause chattering. The rule of thumb is that the blade is 90 degrees to the glass mid-swipe The reason for mid-swipe is it will change angle from the top of the windshield to the bottom of the windshield due to the curvature of the glass.

steps.title: Turn on the ignition and wet the windshield with wiper fluid to test the new wipers for proper installation.
steps.content: Turn on the ignition and wet the windshield with wiper fluid to test the new wipers for proper installation. If the new wipers are streaky, first try cleaning the rubber insert with alcohol wipes or a cloth soaked in mineral spirits. If the wipers are still streaky, check that the blades are properly installed. Verify that you’ve installed each blade on the correct side and check that the wiper is properly oriented. If all else fails, stop by your local auto-parts store for help.

steps.title: Begin by locating the pads at end of the blade; the pads should have small tabs sticking out.
steps.content: Begin by locating the pads at end of the blade; the pads should have small tabs sticking out. Push in the tabs and pull up on the blade to slip it off the assembly. If you find pushing the tabs in to be difficult, you can use a pair of needle-nose pliers to help you. On some models, the wiper arm must be removed so that the rubber insert can be replaced correctly.

steps.title: Slide the rubber insert off of the wiper arm.
steps.content: Slide the rubber insert off of the wiper arm. Once the tabs are past the blade clamp (near the center of the blade), release the tabs and pull the rubber insert completely free of the arm. [6] X Research source The blade is now exposed, and, if left in the standing position, it can snap back and damage your windshield. To be safe, gently place the bare blades back against the windshield until you’re ready to put on the new rubber inserts. To be extra safe, place a rag or cloth underneath the blade while it rests against the windshield.

steps.title: Take out the new rubber insert.
steps.content: Take out the new rubber insert. If the left and right wipers are different sizes, be sure to match the new insert to the correct blade. Slide the new rubber insert onto the blade, starting at the same end you just pulled the old one away from. [7] X Research source When the insert is in place, be sure the clamps on the blade are securely holding it in place. Verify that the far pad is secured in place by the last clamp.

steps.title: Gently push the blade back down to a resting position against the windshield and then repeat with the other rubber insert.
steps.content: Gently push the blade back down to a resting position against the windshield and then repeat with the other rubber insert. If the new wipers are streaky, first try cleaning the rubber insert with alcohol wipes or a cloth soaked in mineral spirits. If the wipers are still streaky, check that the blades are properly installed: verify that you’ve installed each blade on the correct side and check that the wiper is properly oriented. If all else fails, stop by your local auto-parts store for help.
